metadata.case_name: Workmen v. Dunlop Rubber Company (India) Limited

facts.text: Respondent Dunlop Rubber Company of India Limited engaged in manufacture and sale of tyres and tubes, factories in Calcutta and Ambattur (Madras, started about 1959).
At time of award, company employing about 1200 workmen; during 1962 and 1963, about 800 workmen.
Company paid workmen 12 weeks basic wages as annual bonus for each of 1962 and 1963.
Workmen dissatisfied, demanded additional bonus of three months basic wages for each year, claiming net profit of about Rs. 3.30 crores each year.
Company declined demand; Government of Madras referred dispute on additional bonus to Industrial Tribunal, Madras by order dated October 15, 1966 (I.D. No. 65 of 1966).
Tribunal award dated October 29, 1967 declined additional bonus for 1962 and 1963, accepting management's case.
Company claimed paid bonus equivalent to fifteen weeks basic wages (60-63% of available surplus); all workmen except Ambattur (12% of total) accepted.
Workmen claimed unjust deductions from gross profit per Full Bench Formula, esp. Rs. 2.49 crores rehabilitation.

Disputes on deductions: commission receivable (Rs. 3,94,964/3,94,973), royalties (Rs.59,191/50,580), profit on fixed assets, provision for retirement gratuities written back, return on share premium (Rs.4,20,000 each year), donations (1962), return on reserves as working capital (Rs.23,35,009/24,90,563), rehabilitation.
Company filed Ext. M-3 showing available surplus Rs.65,90,465 (1962) and Rs.80,29,190 (1963) subject to rehabilitation.

legal_issues.text: Whether workmen entitled to additional bonus for 1962 and 1963 beyond amount already paid, considering deductions per Full Bench Formula including commission, royalties, share premium return, donations, working capital return, rehabilitation.

petitioner_arguments.text: Company made unjustified deductions from gross profit per Full Bench Formula; huge rehabilitation Rs.2.49 crores to defeat demands; net profits Rs.3.30/3.27 crores justify 3 months additional bonus.
Commission and royalties earned with workmen contribution, should be added back.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen

petitioner_arguments.text: No return on share premium as not paid-up capital.
Return on reserves as working capital not proved by proper evidence.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Oriental Gas Company Ltd. v. Workmen; Bareilly Electricity Supply Co. Ltd. v. Workmen

petitioner_arguments.text: No claim for rehabilitation as per Ext. M-3 phrasing.

respondent_arguments.text: Paid 15 weeks equivalent bonus (60-63% available surplus) per Full Bench Formula; only Ambattur workmen (12%) dissatisfied.
Commission/royalties extraneous income, no labour contribution (Notes 1-2 Ext.M-3, MW-1 evidence).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Workmen of Hindustan Motors Ltd. v. Hindustan Motors Ltd.

respondent_arguments.text: Share premium is capital per Companies Act, entitled to 6% return.
Donations (incl. National Defence Fund) properly deducted.
Return on working capital proved via Exts. M-8, M-9, MW-1, MW-2 evidence, no cross-examination.
Rehabilitation claim supported by Exts. M-15 to M-17, MW-2,3,4 evidence; prior Calcutta Tribunal award Ext.M-26 allowed similar.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Hindustan Motors Ltd.; prior Tribunal award 1960

court_reasoning.text: Commission and royalties are extraneous income like home delivery commission; no workmen contribution (Notes 1-2, MW-1 evidence, no cross-exam); deduction justified.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Analogous to Hindustan Motors case; Tata Oil distinguished.

court_reasoning.text: Gratuities written back deduction conceded unjustified by respondent.
Share premium is capital (Rights issue premium, per Companies Act), entitled to 6% return (MW-1 evidence).
Donations (1962) not deductible (Voltas Ltd.; conceded by respondent).
Return on working capital proved (Exts.M-8,M-9, MW-1,MW-2, no cross-exam); not mere balance-sheet.
Even without rehabilitation, available surplus Rs.67,09,504 (1962)/Rs.86,25,247 (1963); paid 66%/60-62% bonus, sufficient (>60% norm, tax rebate benefit).
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to fully assess rehabilitation (evidence unchalleged before Tribunal).

holdings.text: Deductions for commission/royalties, share premium return, working capital return justified; donations not deductible; even sans rehabilitation, bonus paid sufficient per Full Bench Formula precedents.
Workmen not entitled to additional bonus for 1962-1963.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tata Oil Mills Co. Ltd. v. Its Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Income earned in normal course of business with labour contribution included in surplus; not applicable to extraneous commission/royalties.

precedents_cited.case_name: Workmen of Hindustan Motors Ltd. v. Hindustan Motors Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Home delivery commission extraneous; similar to company's commission/royalties; approved Tata principle but distinguished facts.

precedents_cited.case_name: Oriental Gas Company Ltd. v. Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Evidence required for return on working capital beyond balance-sheet.

precedents_cited.case_name: Bareilly Electricity Supply Co. Ltd. v. Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: Proof of reserves used as working capital by affidavit etc., opportunity to cross-examine.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gannon Dunkerley and Co. Ltd. v. Their Workmen
precedents_cited.relevance: 60% allocation to workmen as correct proportion.

statutes_cited.name: Companies Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Share premium shown separately, treated as capital not distributable as dividend.

outcome.summary: Appeal by workmen against Tribunal award denying additional bonus for 1962-1963 dismissed; court upheld most management deductions, found bonus paid (15 weeks equiv., >60% surplus) sufficient even without rehabilitation claim.

key_quotes.text: "the amounts received by the company, by way of commission and royalties, are analogous to the home delivery commission, which was held by this Court in Workmen of M S Hindustan Motors Ltd. v. MIS Hindustan Motors Ltd. to be extraneous income."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "even without allowing any claim for rehabilitation, the workmen have been paid bonus for the two years in question at rates higher than 60."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core finding rendering additional claims moot.

key_quotes.text: "Considering the matter from any point of view, there is no question of the workmen being entitled to any additional bonus over and above what has already been paid."
key_quotes.speaker: court
